editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Any thing for a quiet life.
A comedy, formerly acted at Blackfriars, by his late majesty's servants.
London: printed by Tho. Johnson for Francis Kirkman, and Henry marsh, and are to be sold at the prince's arms in chancery-lane. 1662.

list.item: George Cressingham, son to sir Francis.
Franklin a sea-captain, son to old franklin, and companion to George Cressingham.
Knavesbee a lawyer, and pander to his wife â–ª
Selenger, page to the lord Beaufort.
George and Ralph, two prentices to water Chamlet.
Fleshhook and counterbuff, a sergeant and a yeoman.
Two children of sir Francis Cressingham's, nursed by water Chamlet.
Lady Cressingham, wife to sir Francis.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: Howe'er th'intents and appetites of men
Are different as their faces, how and when
T'employ their actions, yet all without strife
Meet in this point, any thing for a quiet life.
Nor is there one I think that's hither come
For his delight, but would find peace at home
On any terms. The lawyer does not cease
To talk himself into a sweat with pain,
And so his fees buy quiet, 'tis his gain:
The poor man does endure the scorching sun,
And feels no weariness his day-labor done,
So his wife entertain him with a smile,
And thank his travail, though she slept the while:
This being in men of all conditions true,
Does give our play a name; and if to you
It yield content, and usual delight,
For our parts we shall sleep secure tonight .

div.head: Any thing for a quiet life.
Actus i.
div.stage: Enter the lord Beaufort, and sir Francis Cressingham.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Away, I am ashamed of your proceedings, and seriously you have in this one act overthrown the reputation the world held of your wisdom.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Can you not see your error? that having buried so good a wife not a month since; one that, to speak the truth, had all those excellencies which our books have only feigned to make a complete wife, most exactly in her in practice, and to marry a girl of fifteen; one bred up i'th court, that by all consonancy of reason, is like to cross your estate: why, one new gown of hers when 'tis paid for, will eat you out the keeping of a bountiful Christmas. I am ashamed of you, for you shall make too dear a proof of it, I fear; that in the election of a wife, as in a project of war, to err but once, is to be undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Good my lord, I do beseech you let your better judgement go along with your reprehension.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: So it does, and can find naught to extenuate your fault, but your dotage: you are a man well sunk in years, and to graft such a young blossom into your stock, is the next way to make every carnal eye bespeak your injury. Troth I pity her too, she was not made to wither and go out by painted fires, that yields her no more heat, than to be lodged in some bleak banqueting-house i'th dead of winter, and what follows then? your shame, and the ruin of your children, and there's the end of a rash bargain.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p:
With your pardon, that she is young is true; but that discretion has gone beyond her years â–ª and overta'en those of maturer age, does more improve her goodness. I confess she was bred at court, but so retiredly, that (As still the best in some place is to be learned there) so her life did rectify itself more by the court chapel, then by the office of the revels: best of all virtues are
to be found at court, and where you meet with writings contrary to this known truth, they are framed by men that never were so happy to be planted there to know it: for the difference between her youth and mine, if you will read a matron's sober staidness in her eye, and all the other grave demeanour fitting the governess of a house, you'll then confess there's no disparity between us.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Come, come, you readEnter Mr. water Chamletwhat you would have her to be, not what she is. O Mr. water Chamlet, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: I thank your lordship.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And what news stirring in Cheapside?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Nothing new there my lord, but the standard.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: O that's a monument your wives take great delight in; I do hear you are grown a mighty purchaser, I hope shortly to find you a continual resident upon the North isle of the exchange.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Where? with the Scotchmen?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: No sir, with the aldermen.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Believe it, I am a poor commoner.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Come, you are warm, and blessed with a fair wife.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: There's it, her going brave, has the only virtue to improve my credit in the subsidy-book.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But I pray, how thrives your new plantation of silkworms, those I saw last summer at your garden?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: They are removed sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Whether?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: This winter my wife has removed them home to a fair chamber, where divers courtiers use to come and see them, and my wife carries them up; I think shortly, what with the store of visitants, they'll prove as chargeable to me as the morrow after Simon and Jude, only excepting the taking down and setting up again of my glass-windows.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: That a man of your estate should be so gripple-minded, and repining at his wife's bounty!

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: There are no such ridiculous things i'th world, as those love money better than themselves; for though they have understanding to know riches, and a mind to seek them, and a wit to find them, and policy to keep them, and long life to possess them; yet commonly they have withal such a false sight, such bleard-eyes, all their wealth when it lies before them, does seem poverty, and such a one are you.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p:
Good sir Francis, you have had sore eyes too, you have
been a gamester, but you have given it o'er, and to redeem the vice belonged to't, now you entertain certain farcels of silenced ministers, which I think will equally undo you â–ª yet should these waste you but lenitively, your devising new water-mill for recovery of drowned land, and certain dreams you have in alchemy to find the philosophers-stone, will certainly draw you to'th bottom: I speak freely sir, and would not have you angry, for I love you.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: I am deeply in your books for furnishing my late wedding; have you brought a note of the particulars?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: No sir, at more leisure.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: What comes the sum to?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: For tissue, cloth of gold, velvets and silks, about fifteen hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Your money is ready.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: And how does my two young children, whom I have put to board with you?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Have you put forth two of your children already?

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: 'Twas my wife's discretion to have it so.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Come, 'tis the first principle in a mother-in-law's chop-logic, to divide the family, to remove from forth your sight the object, that her cunning knows would dull her insinuation: had you been a kind father, it would have been your practice every day to have preached to these two young ones carefully, your late wife's funeral sermon. 'las poor souls, are they turned so soon a grazing?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: My lord, they are placed where they shall be respected as mine own.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I make no question of it, good Mr. Chamlet. See here your eldest son, frank Cressingham!

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: You have displeased and grieved your mother in law, and till you have made submission and procured her pardon, I'll not know you for my son.

sp.speaker: George Cress.
sp.p: I have wrought her no offence sir, the difference grew about certain jewels which my mother (By your consent) lying upon her deathbed, bequeathed to her three children; these I demanded, and being denied these, thought this sin of hers to violate so gentle a request of her predecessor, was an ill foregoing of a mother in laws harsh nature.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Sir, understand my will moved in her denial: you have jewels to pawn, or sell them! Sirrah, I will have you as obedient to this woman as to myself, till then you are none of mine.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: O Mr. George, be ruled, do any thing for a quiet life, your father's peace of life moves in it too. I have a wife, when she is in the sullens, like a cook's dog that you see turn a wheel, she will be sure to go and hide herself out of the way dinner and supper: and in these fits Bowe-bell is a still organ to her, when we were married first, I well remember, her railing did appear but a vision, till certain scratches on my hand and face, assured me it was substantial. She's a creature uses to way lay my faults, and more desires to find them out, then to have them amended: she has a book, which I may truly nominate her blackbook, for she remembers in it in short items all my misdemeanours: as, item such a day I was got foxed with foolish metheglin, in the company of certain Welsh chapmen. Item, such a day being at the artillery-garden, one of my neighbours in courtesy to salute me with his musket, set a fire my fustian and apes breeches. Such a day I lost fifty pound in hugger-mugger , at dice at the quest-house. Item I lent money to a sea-captain, on his bare confound him he would pay me again the next morning, and such like; for which she railed upon me when I should sleep, and that's, you know, intolerable; for indeed 'twill tame an elephant.

sp.speaker: George Cress.
sp.p: 'Tis a shrewd vexation, but your discretion sir, does bear it out with a month's sufferance.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Yes, and I would wish you to follow mine example.

sp.speaker: Franklin.
sp.p: Here's small comfort George from your father. Here's a lord whom I have long depended upon for employment, I will see if my suit will thrive better. Please your lordship, you know I am a younger brother, and my fate throwing me upon the late ill-starred voyage to Guiana; failing of our golden hopes, I and my ship addressed ourselves to serve the Duke of Florence.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Yes, I understood so.

sp.speaker: Franklin.
sp.p: Who gave me both encouragement and means, to do him some small service 'gainst the Turk; being settled there both in his pay and trust, your lordship minding to rig forth a ship to trade for the East-indies, sent for me, and what your promise was, if I would leave so great a fortune to become your servant, your letters yet can witness.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Yes, what follows?

sp.speaker: Franklin.
sp.p:
That for ought I perceive, your former purpose is
quite forgotten; I have stayed here two months, and find your intended voyage but a dream, and the ship you talk of as imaginary, as that the astronomers point at in the clouds. I have spent two thousand ducats since my arrival; men that have command, my lord, at sea, cannot live ashore without money.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Know sir, a late purchase which cost me a great sum, has diverted me from my former purpose, besides suits in law do every term so trouble me by land, I have forgotten going by water. If you please to rank yourself among my followers, you shall be welcome, and I'll make your means better than any gentleman's I keep.

sp.speaker: Franklin.
sp.p: Some twenty mark a year! will that maintain scarlet and goldlace, play at th' ordinary, and beavers at the tavern?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I had thought to prefer you to have been captain of a ship that's bound for the Red-sea.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What hinders it?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why certainly the merchants are possessed you have been a pirate.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Say I were one still, if I were passed the line once, why methinks I should do them better service.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Pray forbear: here's a gentleman whose business must engross me wholly.

sp.speaker: George Cress.
sp.p: What's he, dost thou know him?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A pox upon him, a very knave and rascal, that goes a hunting with the penal statutes; and good for naught but to persuade their lords to rack their rends, and give o'er housekeeping; such caterpillars may hang at their lords ears, when better men are neglected.

sp.speaker: George Cress.
sp.p: What's his name?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Knavesbee.

sp.speaker: George Cress.
sp.p: Knavesbee!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
One that deals in a tenth share about projections: he and his partners when they have got a suit once passed the seal, will so wrangle about partition, and sometimes they fall to'th ears about it, like your fencers, that cudgel one another by patent; you shall see him so terribly bedashed in a Michaelmas term coming from Westminster, that you would swear he were lighted from a horse-race: hang him, hang him, he's a scurvy informer, has more cozenage in him, then is in five travelling lotteries. To feed a kite with the carrion of this knave when he's dead, and reclaim her, o she would prove an excellent hawk for talon: has
a fair creature to his wife too, and a witty rogue it is, and some men think this knave will wink at small faults; but honest George, what shall become of us now?

sp.speaker: George Cress.
sp.p: I'faith I am resolved to set up my rest for the Low-countreys.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: To serve there?

sp.speaker: G. Cress.
sp.p: Yes certain.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: There's thin commons, besides they have added one day more to'th week then was in the creation; art thou valiant? Art thou valiant, George?

sp.speaker: Geo. Cress.
sp.p: I may be, and I be put to't.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: O never fear that, thou canst not live two hours after thy landing without a quarrel. Thou must resolve to fight, or like a sumner, thou'lt be bastinadoed at every town's end. You shall have gallants there as ragged as the fall o'th leaf, that live in holland, where the finest linen's made, and yet wear never a shirt: these will not only quarrel with a newcomer when they are drunk, but they will quarrel with any man has means to be drunk afore them: follow my council, George, thou shalt not go o'er, we'll live here i'th city.

sp.speaker: Ceo. Cress.
sp.p: But how?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: How? why, as other gallants do that feed high, and play copiously, yet brag they have but nine pound a year to live on: these have wit to turn rich fools and gulls into quarter-days, that bring them in certain payment. I have a project reflects upon yon mercer, Mr. Chamlet, shall put us into money.

sp.speaker: George Cress.
sp.p: What is't?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Nay, I will not stale it aforehand, 'tis a new one: nor cheating amongst gallants may seem strange, why a reaching wit goes currant on th'exchange.

sp.speaker: Knavesbee.
sp.p: O my lord, I remember you and I were students together at Cambridge; but believe me you went far beyond me.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: When I studied there, I had so fantastical a brain, that like a phelphare, frighted in winter by a birding-piece, I could settle nowhere ; here and there a little of every several art, and away.

sp.speaker: Knavesbee.
sp.p:
Now my wit, though it were more dull, yet I went slowly on, and as divers others, when I could not prove an excellent scholar by a plodding patience, I attained to be a petty lawyer; and I thank my dulness for't, you may stamp in lead any figure, but in oil or quicksilver nothing can be imprinted, for
they keep no certain station.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: O, you tax me well of irresolution; but say worthy friend, how thrives my weighty suit which I have trusted to your friendly bosom? is there any hope to make me happy?

sp.speaker: Knavesbee.
sp.p: 'Tis yet questionable, for I have not broke the ice to her; an hour hence come to my house, and if it lie in man, be sure, as the law phrase says, I will create you lord Paramount of your wishes.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: O my best friend, and one that takes the hardest course i'th world, to make himself so. Sir, now I'll take my leave.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Nay good my lord, my wife is coming down.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Pray pardon me, I have business so importunes me o'th sudden, I cannot stay; deliver mine excuse, and in your ear this. Let not a fair woman make you forget your children.

sp.speaker: La. Cress.
sp.p: What? are you taking leave too?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Yes, good madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cress.
sp.p: The rich stuff which my husband bought of you, the works of them are too common: I have got a Dutch painter to draw patterns, which I'll have sent to your factors; as in Italy, at Florence and Ragusa, where these stuffs are woven, to have pieces made for mine own wearing of a new invention.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: You may lady, but 'twill be somewhat chargeable.

sp.speaker: La. Cress.
sp.p: Chargeable! what of that? if I live another year, I'll have my agents shall lie for me at Paris, and at Venice, and at Validolet in Spain, for intelligence of all new fashions.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Do sweetest, thou deservest to be exquisite in all things.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: The two children to which you are mother in law, would be repaired too, 'tis time they had new clothing.

sp.speaker: La. Cress.
sp.p: I pray fir, do not trouble me with them; they have a father indulgent and careful of them.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: I am sorry you made the motion to her.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I have done: he has run himself
Into a pretty dotage, madam, with your leave;
He's tied to a new law, and a new wife,
Yet to my old proverb, any thing for a quiet life.

sp.speaker: La. Cress.
sp.p: Good friend, I have a suit to you.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Dearest self â–ª you most powerfully sway me.

sp.speaker: La. Cress.
sp.p:
That you would give o'er this fruitless, if I may not say this idle, study of alchemy; why half your house looks like a
glass-house.

sp.speaker: Saunder.
sp.p: And the smoke you make is a worse enemy to good housekeeping, than tobacco.

sp.speaker: La. Cress.
sp.p: Should one of your glasses break, it might bring you to a dead palsy.

sp.speaker: Saunder.
sp.p: My lord, your quicksilver has made all your more solid gold and silver fly in fume.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: I'll be ruled by you in any thing.

sp.speaker: La. Cress.
sp.p: Go Saunder, break all the glasses.

sp.speaker: Saunder.
sp.p: I fly to't.

sp.speaker: La. Cress.
sp.p: Why noble friend, would you find the true philosophers-stone indeed, my good housewifry should do it. You understand I was bred up with a great courtly lady, do not think all women mind gay clothes and riot, there are some widows living have improved both their own fortunes and their children's: would you take my counsel, I'd advise you to sell your land.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: My land!

sp.speaker: La. Cress.
sp.p: Yes, and the manor house up n't, 'tis rotten: o the new fashioned buildings brought from the Hague! 'tis stately. I have intelligence of a purchase, and the title sound, will for half the money you may sell yours for, bring you in more rent than yours now yields you.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: If it be so good a pennyworth, I need not sell my land to purchase it, I'll procure money to do it.

sp.speaker: La. Cress.
sp.p: Where sir?

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Why, I'll take it up at interest.

sp.speaker: La Cress.
sp.p: Never did any man thrive that purchased with use-money.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: How come you to know these thrifty principles?

sp.speaker: La. Cress.
sp.p:
How? Why my father was a lawyer, and died in the commission, and may not I by a natural instinct, have a reaching that way: there are on mine own knowledge some divines daughters infinitely affected with reading controversies, and that some think has been a means to bring so many suits into the spiritual court. Pray be advised, sell your land, and purchase more: I knew a pedlar by being merchant this way, is become lord of many manors: we should look to lengthen our estatesEnt. Saunder.as we do our lives; and though I am young, yet I am confident your able constitution of body when you are passed fourscore, shall keep you fresh till I arrive at the neglected year that I am past child-bearing, and yet ever there quickening our faint heats in a soft embrace, and kindling divine flames in fervent prayers, we
may both go out together, and one tomb quit our executors the rites of two.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: O you are so wise, and so good in every thing, I move by your direction.

sp.speaker: Saunder.
sp.p: She has caught him!

div.head: Actus. Ii.
div.stage: Enter Knavesbee and his wife. Table.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Have you drunk the eggs and muskadine I sent you?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No, they are too fulsome.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Away, you're a fool, how shall I begin to break the matter to her? I do long, wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Long, sir!

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Long infinitely. Sit down, there is a penitential motion in me, which if thou wilt but second, I shall be one of the happiest men in Europe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What might that be?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I had last night one of the strangest dreams; methought I was thy confessor, thou mine, and we revealed between us privately how often we had wronged each others bed since we were married.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Came you drunk to bed? there was a dream with a witness.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: No, no witness; I dreamt nobody heard it but we two. This dream wife, do I long to put in act, let us confess each other, and I vow whatever thou hast done with that sweet corpse in the way of natural frailty, I protest most freely I will pardon.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Go sleep again; was there ever such a motion?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Nay sweet woman, and thou wilt not have me run mad with my desire, be persuaded to't.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Well, be it your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: But to answer truly.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Oh most sincerely.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Begin then; examine me first.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why, I know not what to ask you.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Let me see, your father was a captain; demand of me how many dead pays I am to answer for in the muster-book of wedlock, by the martial fault of borrowing from my neighbours?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Troth I can ask no such foolish questions

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p:
Why then open confession I hope dear wife, will merit freer pardon: I sinned twice with my laundress, and last circuit there was at Banbury a she-chamberlain that had a spice of purity,
but at last I prevailed over her.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O, you are an ungracious husband.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I have made a vow never to ride abroad but in thy company; o a little drink makes me clamber like a monkey: now sweet wife, you have been an outlier too, which is best feed in the forest, or in the purlieus?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: A foolish mind of you i' this.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Nay sweet love, confess freely, I have given you the example.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why you know I went last year to Sturbidge-fair.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And being in Cambridge, a handsome scholar, one of Emanuel college, fell in love with me.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: O you sweet-breathed monkey.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Go hang, you are so boisterous.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: But did this scholar show thee his chamber?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: And didst thou like him?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Like him! o he had the most enticingst straw-coloured beard, a woman with black eyes would have loved him like jet: he was the finest man with a formal wit; and he had a fine dog that sure was whelped i'th college, for he understood Latin.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Pue wawe, this is nothing, till I know what he did in's chamber.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: He burned wormwood in't, to kill the fleas i'th rushes.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: But what did he to thee there?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Some five and twenty years hence I may chance tell you. Fie upon you, what tricks? what crotchets are these? have you placed anybody behind the arras to hear my confession? I heard one in England got a divorce from's wife by such a trick; were I disposed now, I would make you as mad. You shall see me play the changeling.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: No, no wife, you shall see me play the changeling: hadst thou confessed, this other suit I'll now prefer to thee, would have been dispatched in a trice.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And what's that sir?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Thou wilt wonder at it four and twenty years longer than nine days.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I would very fain hear it.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: There is a lord o'th court, upon my credit a most dear, honourable friend of mine, that must lie with thee. Do you laugh? 'tis not come to that, you'll laugh when you know who 'tis.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Are you stark mad?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p:
On my religion I have passed my word for't, 'tis the lord Beaufort, thou art made happy for ever, the generous and bountiful lord Beaufort: you being both so excellent, 'twere pity if such
rare pieces should not be conferred, and sampled together.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Do you mean seriously?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: As I hope for preferment.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And can you lose me thus?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Lose you! I shall love you the better: why, what's the viewing any wardrobe, or jewelhouse, without a companion to confer their likings? yet now I view thee well, methinks thou art a rare monopoly, and great pity one man should enjoy thee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: This is pretty.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Let's divorce ourselves so long, or think I am gone to'th' Indies, or lie with him when I am asleep, for some Familists of Amsterdam will tell you may be done with a safe conscience: come you wanton, what hurt can this do to you? I protest nothing so much as to keep company with an old woman has sore eyes: no more wrong than I do my beaver when I try it thus. Look, this is all; smooth, and keeps fashion still.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You are one of the basest fellows.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I looked for chiding, I do make this a kind of fortitude the Romans never dreamt of, and 'twere known, I should be spoke and writ of when I am rotten, for 'tis beyond example.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: But I pray resolve me: suppose this done, could you ever love me after?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I protest I never thought so well of thee, till I knew he took a fancy to thee; like one that has variety of choice meat before him, yet has no stomach to 't until he hear another praise: hark, my lord is coming.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Possible.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: And my preferment comes along with him; be wise, mind your good, and to confute all reason in the world which thou canst urge against it when 'tis done, we will be married again wife, which some say is the only supersedeas about Limehouse, to remove cuckoldry.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Come, are you ready to attend me to the court?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Yes my lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Is this fair one, your wife?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: At your lordship's service; I will look up some writings, and return presently.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: To see and the base fellow do not leave's alone too!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: 'Tis an excellent habit this, where were you born, sweet?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I am a Suffolk woman, my lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Believe it, every country you breathe on, is the sweeter for you: let me see your hand. The case is loath to part with the jewel: fairest one, I have skill in palmistry.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Good my lord, what do you find there?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: In good earnest I do find written here, all my good fortune lies in your hand.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You'll keep a very bad house then, you may see by the smallness of the table.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Who is your sweetheart?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sweetheart!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Yes, come, I must sift you to know it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I am a sieve too course for your lordship's manchet.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Nay, pray you tell me, for I see your husband is an unhandsome fellow.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O my lord, I took him by weight, not fashion: goldsmiths wives taught me that way of bargain, and some ladies swerve not to follow the example.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But will you not tell me who is your private friend?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes, and you'll tell me who is yours.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Shall I show you her?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes, when will you?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Instantly, look you there you may see her.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I'll break the glass, 'tis now worth nothing.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You have made it a flattering one.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I have a summer-house for you; a fine place to flatter solitariness: will you come and lie there?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No my lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Your husband has promised me: will you not?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I must wink I tell you, or say nothing.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: So, I'll kiss you and wink too,
Midnight is Cupid's holiday.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: By this time 'tis concluded: will you go my lord?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I leave with you my best wishes till I see you.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: This now (If I may borrow our lawyer's phrase) is my wife's imparlance, at her next appearance she must answer your declaration.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You follow it well, sir.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Did I not know my husband of so base contemptible nature, I should think 'twere but a trick to try me; but it seems they are both in wicked earnest; and methinks upon the sudden I have a great mind to loathe this scurvy unhandsome way my lord has ta'en to compass me: why 'tis for all the world as if he should come
to steal some apricots my husband kept for's own tooth, and climb up upon his head and shoulders. I'll go to him, he will put me into brave clothes, and rich jewels; 'twere a very ill part in me not to go, his mercer and his goldsmith else might curse me; and what I'll do there, a my troth yet I know not; women though puzzled with these subtle deeds, may, as i'th spring, pick physic out of weeds.

div.stage: Enter (A shop being discovered) Walter Chamlet, his wife Rachel, two prentices, George and Ralph.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: What is't you lack, you lack, you lack?
Stuffs for the belly, or the back?
Silk-grograns, satins, velvet fine,
The rosy-coloured carnadine;
Your nutmeg hue, or gingerline,
Cloth of tissue, or tobine,
That like beaten gold will shine
In your amorous lady's eyne,
Whilst you their softer silks do twine:Enter Rachel.
What is't you lack, you lack, you lack?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: I do lack content sir, content I lack: have you or your worshipful master here, any content to sell?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: If content be a stuff to be sold by the yard, you may have content at home, and never go abroad for't.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Do, cut me three yards, I'll pay for 'em.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: There's all we have i'th shop; we must know what you'll give for 'em first.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Why Rachel, sweet Rachel, my bosom Rachel, how didst thou get forth? thou wert here sweet Rac. within this hour, even in my very heart.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Away, or stay still, I'll away from thee, one bed shall never hold us both again, nor one roof cover us: didst thou bring home

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: What is't you lack, you lack, you lack?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Peace bandog, bandog, give me leave to speak, or I'll

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Shall I not follow my trade? I'm bound to't, and my master bound to bring me up in't.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Peace, good George, give her anger leave, thy mistress will be quiet presently.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Quiet! I defy thee and quiet too: quiet thy bastards thou hast brought home.

sp.speaker: George and Ralph.
sp.p: What is't you lack, you lack? Etc.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Death, give me an ell, has one bawling cur raised up another? two dogs upon me, and the old bearward will not succour me, I'll stave 'em off myself: give me an ell, I say.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Give her not an inch, master, she'll take two ells if you do.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Peace George and Ralph, no more words I charge you; and Rachel, sweet wife, be more temperate, I know your tongue speaks not by the rule and guidance of your heart, when you proclaim the pretty children of my virtuous and noble kinswoman, whom in life you knew above my praises reach, to be my bastards; this is not well, although your anger did it, pray chide your anger for it.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Sir, sir, your gloss of kinswoman cannot serve turn, 'tis stale, and smells too rank, though your shop wares you vent with your deceiving lights, yet your chamber stuff shall not pass so with me; I say, and I will prove.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: What is't you lack?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Why George, I say.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Lecher I say, I'll be divorced from thee, I'll prove 'em thy bastards, and thou insufficient.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What said my angry cousin to you sir? that we were bastards?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: I hope she meant not us.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: No, no, my pretty cousins, she meant George and Ralph; rage will speak any thing, but they are never the worse.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes indeed forsooth she spoke to us, but chiefly to Ralph, because she knows he has but one stone.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: No more of that if you love me, George, this is not the way to keep a quiet house.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Truly sir, I would not for more treasure than ever I saw yet, be in your house a cause of discord.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: And do you think I would, sister?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No indeed, Ned.
sp.stage: Ent. Frank. And young Cress. disguised

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: Why did you not speak for me with you then, and said we could not have done so?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: No more sweet cousins now: speak George, customers approach.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Is the barber prepared?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: With ignorance enough to go through with it, so near I am to him, we must call cousins, would thou wert as sure to hit the tailor.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: If I do not steal away handsomely, let me never play the tailor again.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: What is't you lack? Etc.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Good satins sir.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: The best in Europe, sir; here's a piece worth a piece every yard of him, the King of Naples wears no better silk; mark his gloss, he dazzles the eye to look upon him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Is he not gummed?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Gummed! he has neither mouth nor tooth, how can he be gummed?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Very pretty.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: An especial good piece of silk, the worm never spun a finer thread, believe it, sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Gascoyn, you have some skill in it.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Your tailor, sir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: A good piece, sir; but let's see more choice.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Taylor, drive thorough, you know your bribes.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Mum: he bestows forty pounds, if I say the word.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Strike through, there's poundage for you then.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I marry! I like this better, what sayst thou, Gascoyn?

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: A good piece indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: The great Turk has worse satin at's elbow, than this sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: The price?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Look on the mark, George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: O. souse and p, by my facks, sir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: The best sort then, sixteen a yard, nothing to be bated.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Fie sir, fifteen's too high, yet so, for how many yards will serve for my suit, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Nine yards, you can have no less, sir Andrew.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But I can sir, if you please to steal less; I had but eight in my last suit.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: You pinch us too near in faith, sir Andrew.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yet can you pinch out a false pair of sleeves to a freezado doublet.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: No sir, some purses and pin-pillows perhaps: a tailor pays for his kissing that ways.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Well sir, eight yards, eight fifteens I give, and cut it.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: I cannot truly, sir.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: My master must be no subsidy-man sir, if he take such fifteens.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I am at highest sir, if you can take money.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Well sir, I'll give you the buying once, I hope to gain it in your custom: want you nothing else, sir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Not at this time, sir.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Indeed but you do, sir Andrew, I must needs deliver my lady's message to you, she enjoined me by oath to do it, she commanded me to move you for a new gown.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sirrah, I'll break your head, if you motion it again.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: I must endanger myself for my lady, sir: you know she's to go to my lady Trenchmore's wedding, and to be seen there without a new gown, she'll have never an eye to be seen there, for her fingers in 'em: nay by my fack, sir, I do not think she'll go, and then the cause known, what a discredit 't will be to you!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Not a word more, goodman Snip-snapper for your ears: what comes this to, sir?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Six pound, sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: There's your money: will you take this, and be gone, and about your business presently?

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Troth sir, I'll see some stuffs for my lady first, I'll tell her at least I did my good will; a fair piece of cloth of silver, pray you now.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Or cloth of gold if you please sir, as rich as ever the sophy wore.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You are the arrantest villain of a tailor, that ever sat cross-legged: what do you think a gown of this stuff will come to?

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Why say it be forty pound sir: what's that to you? three thousand a year I hope will maintain it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: It will sir, very good, you were best be my overseer: say I be not furnished with money, how then?

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: A very fine excuse in you, which place of ten now will you send me for a hundred pound, to bring it presently?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Sir, sir, your tailor persuades you well, 'tis for your credit, and the great content of your lady.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: 'Tis for your content sir, and my charges: never think goodman false-stitch to come to the mercers with me again; pray will you see if my cousin Sweetball the barber (He's nearest hand) be furnished, and bring me word instantly.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: I fly, sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You may fly sir, you have clipped somebody's wings for it to piece out your own; an arrant thief you are.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Indeed he speaks honestly and justly, sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You expect some gain sir, there's your cause of love.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Surely I do a little, sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And what might be the price of this?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: This is thirty a yard; but if you'll go to forty, here's a non pareile.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: So, there's a matter of forty pound for a gown cloth.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Thereabouts, sir; why sir, there are far short of your means that wear the like.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Do you know my means, sir?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: By overhearing your tailor, sir, three thousand a year: but if you'd have a petticoat for your lady, here's a stuff.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Are you another tailor, sirrah? here's a knave, what are you?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: You are such another gentleman; but for the stuff sir, 'tis l. Ss. and K; for the turn stripped a purpose, a yard and a quarter broad too, which is the just depth of a woman's petticoat.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And why stripped for a petticoat?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Because if they abuse their petticoats, there are abuses stripped, then 'tis taking them up, and they may be stripped and whipped too.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Very ingenious.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Then it is likewise stripped standing, between which is discovered the open part, which is now called the placket.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, was it ever called otherwise?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes: while the word remained pure in his original, the Latin tongue, who have no ks, it was called the placet, a placendo, a thing, or place, to please.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Better and worse still: now sir, you come in haste, what says my cousin?

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Protest sir, he's half angry, that either you should think him unfurnished, or not furnished for your use, there's a hundred pound ready for you; he desires you to pardon his coming, his folks are busy, and his wife trimming a gentleman, but at your first approach the money wants but telling.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: He would not trust you with it: I con him thanks, for that he knows what trade you are of: well sir, pray cut him patterns, he may in the mean time know my lady's liking, let your man take the pieces whole, with the lowest princes, and walk with me to my cousins.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: With all my heart, sir: Ralph, your cloak, and go with the gentleman, look you give good measure.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Look you carry a good yard with you.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: The best i'th' shop sir, yet we have none bad: you'll have the stuff for the petticoat too?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No sir, the gown only.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: By all means sir: not the petticoat? that were holiday upon working-day i'faith.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You are so forward for a knave, sir.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: 'Tis for your credit and my ladies both, I do it sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Your man is trusty sir?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: O sir, we keep none but those we dare trust sir. Ralph, have a care of light gold.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I warrant you sir, I'll take none.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Come sirrah: fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Pray know my shop another time, sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: That I shall sir, from all the shops i'th town; 'tis the lamb in Lombardstreet.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: A good morning's work, sir; if this custom would but last long, you might shut up your shop and live privately.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: O George. But here's a grief that takes away all the gains and joy of all my thrift.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: What's that, sir?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Thy mistress, George: her frowardness sours all my comfort.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Alas sir, they are but squibs and crackers, they'll soon die; you know her flashes of old.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: But they fly so near me, that they burn me; George they are as ill as muskets charged with bullets.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: She has discharged herself now sir, you need not fear her.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: No man can love without his affliction, George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: As you cannot without my mistress.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Right, right, there's harmony in discords: this lamp of love while any oil is left, can never be extinct, it may (Like a snuff) wink and seem to die, but up he will again and show his head; I cannot be quiet George, without my wife at home.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: And when she's at home, you're never quiet I'm sure, a fine life you have on't: well sir, I'll do my best to find her, and bring her back if I can.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Do honest George, at Knaves-bee's house, that varlets, there's her haunt and harbour, who enforces a kinsman on her, and calls him cousin:
Restore her George, to ease this heart that's vexed,
The best new suit that e'er thou wore'st is next.

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: I thank you aforehand sir.

div.stage: Enter Franklin, young Cress. as before, Ralph, barber, boy.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p:
Were it of greater moment than you speak of (Noble sir)
I hope you think me sufficient, and it shall be effectually performed.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I could wish your wife did not know it, coz. Women's tongues are not always tuneable, I may many ways requite it.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: Believe me, she shall not sir, which will be the hardest thing of all.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Pray you dispatch him then.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: With the celerity a man tells gold to him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: He hits a good comparison! give my waste-good your stuffs, and go with my cousin sir, he'll presently dispatch you.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: Come with me youth, I am ready for you in my more private chamber.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sirrah go you show your lady the stuffs, and let her choose her colour, away, you know whither: boy, prithee lend me a brush i'th mean time: do you tarry all day now.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: That I will sir, and all night too, ere I come again.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Here's a brush sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A good child.

sp.speaker: Barber within.
sp.p: What Toby.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Anon sir.

sp.speaker: Barber within.
sp.p: Why when, goodman Picklock?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I must attend my master, sir: I come.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Do pretty lad: so, take water at Coleharbour, an easy mercer, and an innocent barber.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: So friend, I'll now dispatch you presently: boy, reach me my dismembering instrument, and let my cauterize be ready; and hark you Snipsnap.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I sir.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: See if my luxinium, my fomentation be provided first, and get my rulers, bolsters, and pleggets armed.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Nay good sir dispatch my business first; I should not stay from my shop.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: You must have a little patience sir, when you are a patient; if prepusium be not too much perished, you shall lose but little by it, believe my art for that.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: What's that sir?

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: Marry if there be exulceration between prepusium and glance, by my faith the whole penis may be endangered as far as os pubes.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: What's this you talk on, sir?

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: If they be gangrened once, testiculi, vesica, and all may run to mortification.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: What a pox does this barber talk on?

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p:
O fie youth, pox is no word of art, morbus Gallicus, or Neopolitanus had been well: come friend, you must not be nice; open
your griefs freely to me.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Why sir, I open my grief to you, I want my money.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: Take you no care for that, your worthy cousin has given me part in hand, and the rest I know he will upon your recovery, and I dare take his word.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Is death, where's my ware?

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: Ware! that was well, the word is cleanly, though not artful; your ware it is that I must see.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: My tobine, and cloth of tissue?

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: You will neither have tissue nor issue, if you linger in your malady: better a member cut off, then endanger the whole microcosm.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Barber, you are not mad?

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: I do begin to fear you are subject to subeth, unkindly sleeps, which have bred oppilations in your brain; take heed, the symptoma will follow, and this may come to frenzy: begin with the first cause, which is the pain of your member.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Do you see my yard, barber?

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: Now you come to the purpose, 'tis that I must see indeed.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: You shall feel it sir: death, give me my fifty pounds, or my ware again, or I'll measure out your anatomy by the yard.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: Boy, my cauterizing-iron red hot.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: 'Tis here, sir.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: If you go further, I take my dismembering knife.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Where's the knight your cousin? the thief, and the tailor with my cloth of gold and tissue?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The gentleman that sent away his man with the stuffs, is gone a pretty while since, he has carried away our new brush.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: O that brush hurts my heart's side: cheated! cheated! he told me that your virga had a burning-fever.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Pox on your virga, barber.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: And that you would be bashful, and ashamed to show your head.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I shall so hereafter, but here it is, you see yet my head, my hair, and my wit, and here are my heels that I must show to my master, if the cheaters be not found; and barber, provide thee plasters, I will break thy head with every basin under the pole.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.l: Cool the luxinium, and quench the cauterizer,
I am partly out of my wits, and partly mad:
My razor's at my heart: these storms will make
My sweet-balls stink, my harmless basins shake.

div.head: Actus iii.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: You're welcome mistress (As I may speak it) but my lord will give it a sweeter emphasis: I'll give him knowledge of you.

sp.speaker: Mris. Knavesb.
sp.p: Good sir stay, methinks it sounds sweetest upon your tongue, I'll wish you to go no further for my welcome.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Mine! it seems you never heard good music, that commend a bagpipe: hear his harmony.

sp.speaker: Mris. Kna.
sp.p: Nay good now, let me borrow of your patience, I'll pay you again before I rise tomorrow, if it please you.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: What would you forsooth?

sp.speaker: Mris. Kna.
sp.p: Your company sir.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: My attendance you should have mistress, but that my lord expects it, and 'tis his due.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: And must be paid upon the hour! that's too strict, any time of the day will serve.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Alas 'tis due every minute, and paid, 'tis due again, or else I forfeit my recognizance, the cloth I wear of his.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: Come, come, pay it double at another time, and 'twil be quit, I have a little use of you.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Of me, forsooth, small use can be made of me: if you have suit to my lord, none can speak-better for you than you may yourself.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: O, but I am bashful.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: So am I in troth, mistress.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: Now I remember me, I have a toy to deliver your lord that's yet unfinished, and you may further me, pray you your hands, while I unwind this skein of gold from you, 'twill not detain you long.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: You wind me into your service prettily; with all the haste you can, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: If it tangle not, I shall soon have done.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: No, it shall not tangle if I can help it, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: If it do I can help it, fear not, this thing of long length you shall see I can bring you to a bottom.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I think so too, if it be not bottomless, this length will reach it

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p:
It becomes you finely, but I forewarn you, and remember it your enemy gain not this advantage of you, you are his prisoner then; for look you, you are mine now, my captive manacled,
I have your hands in bondage.
sp.stage: Grasps the skain between his hands.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: 'Tis a good lesson, mistress, and I am perfect in it, another time I'll take out this, and learn another, pray you release me now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: I could kiss you now spite of your teeth, if it please me.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: But you could not, for I could bite you with the spite of my teeth, if it pleases me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: Well, I'll not tempt you so far, I show it but for rudiment.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: When I go a-wooing , I'll think on't again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: In such an hour I learned it, say I should (In recompense of your hands courtesy) make you a fine wrist-favour of this gold, with all the letters of your name embossed on a soft tress of hair, which I shall cut from mine own fillet, whose ends should meet and close in a fast true-love-knot, would you wear it for my sake, sir?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I think not, truly mistress, my wrists have enough of this gold already, would they were rid on't yet: pray you have done, in troth I'm weary.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: And what a virtue is here expressed in you, which had lain hid but for this trial; weary of gold, sir! O that the close engrossers of this treasure could be so free to put it off of hand, what a new mended world would here be! It shows a generous condition in you, in sooth I think I shall love you dear for't.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: But if they were in prison, as I am, they would be glad to buy their freedom with it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: Surely no, there are that rather than release this dear companion, do lie in prison with it, yes, and will die in prison too.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: 'Twere pity but the hangman did enfranchise both.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Selenger, where are you?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: E'en here, my lord. Mistress, pray you my liberty, you hinder my duty to my lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Nay sir, one courtesy shall serve us both at this time; you're busy I perceive, when your leisure next serves you I would employ you.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: You must pardon me, my lord, you see I am entangled here: mistress I protest I'll break prison, if you free me not, take you no notice?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: O cry your honour mercy, you are now at liberty, sir.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p:
And I'm glad on't, I'll never give both my hands at once again to a woman's command, I'll put one finger
in a hole rather.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Leave us.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Free leave have you, my lord, so I think you may have: filthy beauty, what a white witch thou art!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Lady, you're welcome.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: I did believe it from your page, my lord. Beau. Your husband sent you to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: He did my lord, with duty and commends unto your honour, beseeching you to use me very kindly, by the same token your lordship gave him grant of a new lease of threescore pounds a year, which he and his should forty years enjoy.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: The token's true, and for your sake lady, 'tis likely to be bettered, not alone the lease, but the fee-simple may be his and yours.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: I have a suit unto your lordship too, only myself concerns.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: 'T will be granted sure, though it outvalue thy husbands.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis small charge, only your good will, and good word, my lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: The first is thine confirmed, the second then cannot stay long behind.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: I love your page, sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Love him! for what?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: O, the great wisdoms that our grandsires had! do you ask me reason for't? I love him, because I like him, sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: My page!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: In mine eye, he's a most delicate youth, but in my heart a thing that it would bleed for.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Either your eye is blinded, or your remembrance broken: call to mind wherefore you came hither, lady.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: I do my lord, for love, and I am in profoundly.

sp.speaker: Beau
sp.p: You trifle sure, do you long for unripe fruit? 'twill breed diseases in you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: Nothing but worms in my belly, and there's a seed to expel them; in mellow falling fruit I find no relish.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: 'Tis true, the youngest vines yields the most clusters, but the old ever the sweetest grapes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: I can taste of both sir; but with the old I am the soonest cloyed: the green keep still an edge on appetite.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sure you are a common creature.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p:
Did you doubt it, wherefore came I hither else? Did you think that honesty only had been immured for you, and I should bring it as an offertory unto your shrine of lust? As it was, my lord, 'twas meant to you, had not the slippery wheel of fancy turned when I beheld your page; nay had I seen another before
him in mine eyes better grace, he had been forstalled; but as it is, (All my strength cannot help) beseech you your good will, and good word, my lord, you may command him, sir; if not affection, yet his body, and I desire but that, do't, and I'll command myself your prostitute.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You're a base strumpet, I succeed my page!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: O that's no wonder, my lord, the servant oft tastes to his master of the daintiest dish he brings to him; beseech you, my lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You're a bold mischief, and to make me your spokesman; your procurer to my servant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: Do you shrink at that? why, you have done worse without the sense of ill, with a full free conscience of a libertine: judge your own sin, was it not worse with a damned broking-fee to a corrupt husband, state him a pander to his own wife, by virtue of a lease made to him and your bastard issue, could you get 'em: what a degree of baseness call you this? 'tis a poor sheep-steal provoked by want, compared unto a capital traitor; the master to his servant may be recompensed, but the husband to his wife never.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Your husband shall smart for this.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: Hang him, do, you have brought him to deserve it, bring him to the punishment, there I'll join with you: I loathe him to the gallows, hang your page too, one mourning-gown shall serve for both of them: this trick hath kept mine honesty secure, best soldiers use policy, the lion's skin becomes not the body when 'tis too great, but then the foxes may sit close, and neat.

div.stage: Enter fleshhook, counterbuff, and Sweetball the barber.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: Now fleshhook, use thy talon, set upon his right shoulder; thy sergeant counterbuff at the left, grasp in his jugulars, and then let me alone to tickle his diaphragma.

sp.speaker: Flesh.
sp.p: You are sure he has no protection, sir?

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: A protection to cheat and cozen! there was never any granted to that purpose.

sp.speaker: Flesh.
sp.p: I grant you that too, sir, but that use has been made of 'em.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: Marry has there sir, how could else so many broken bankrupts play up and down by their creditors noses, and we dare not touch 'em?

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p:
That's another case, counter buff, there's privilege to cozen; but here cozenage went before, and there's no privilege
for that; to him boldly, I will spend all the scissors in my shop, but I'll have him snapped.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: Well sir, if he come within the length of large mace once, we'll teach him to cozen.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: Marry hang him, teach him no more cozenage, he's too perfect in't already; go gingerly about it, lay your mace on gingerly, and spice him soundly.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: He's at the tavern, you say?

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: At the man in the moon, above stairs, so soon as he comes down, and the bush left at his back, Ralph is the dog behind him: he watches to give us notice, be ready than my dear Bloodhounds, you shall deliver him to Newgate, from thence to the hangman; his body I will beg of the sheriffs, for at the next lecture I am likely to be the master of my anatomy, then will I vex every vein about him, I will find where his disease of cozenage lay, whether in the vertebrae, or in oscox â–ª index, but I guess I shall find it descend from humour, through the thoric, and lie just at his finger's ends.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Be in readiness, for he's coming this way, alone too; stand to't like gentleman and yeoman, so soon as he is in sight, I'll go fetch my master.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: I have had a conquassition in my cerebrum ever since the disaster, and now it takes me again, if it turn to a megrim, I shall hardly abide the sight of him.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: My action of defamation shall be clapped on him too, I will make him appear to't in the shape of a white sheet all embroidered over with peccavi's: look about, I'll go fetch my master.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: I arrest you, sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ha qui va la, que penses vous fair messieurs, me voles vous derober, je nay point d'argent: je suis un powre gentilhomme Francois.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: Whoop! pray you sir speak English you did when you bought cloth of gold at six nihils a yard, when Ralph's preputium was exulcerated.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Que voules vous, me voules vous tuer; le Francois ne sont point enemis: voila ma bource, que voles vous d'avantage.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: Is not your name franklin, sir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Je na'y point de joiaux que cestui ci; et cest a monsieur l'ambasadeur, il m'en voie a ces afaires et vous enpaiches mon service.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: Sir, we are mistaken for ought I perceive.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: So, so, you have caught him, that's well: how do you sir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Vous sembles estre un homme courtois, je vous prie intends mes affairs: il y a ici deux ou erois quenailles qui m'ont asseige un powre estranger, qui ne leur ay fait nul mal, ny donner mawaisse parrolle, ny tirer mon espet; l'un me prend par une espaule, et me frape deux liure peisant; l'autre me tire par le bras, il par le je ne scay quoy: je leur ay donne ma bource, et si ne me veuleut point laiser aller; que feray je monsieur?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: This is a Frenchman it seems, sirs.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: We can find no other in him, sir, and what that is we know not.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: He's very like the man we seek for, else my lights go false.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: In your shop they may sir, but here they go true: this is he.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: The very same sir, as sure as I am Ralph, this is the rascal.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: Sir, unless you will absolutely challenge him the man, we dare not proceed further.

sp.speaker: Flesh.
sp.p: I fear we are too far already.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: I know not what to say to't.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p: Bon iour, bon iour, gentilhommes.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: How now! more news from France?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ceste femme ici est de mon pais, madame je vous prie leur dire mon pais, il mont retarge je ne scay pour quoy.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p: Estes vous de France monsieur?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Madam vay est, que je les ay tromps, et suis areste, et n'ay nul moien de chaper quan chansant mon language â–ª aides moy en cest affaire: je vous cognois bien, ou vous tenes un Bordeau; vous et les vostre en seres de mieulx.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p: Laises fair a moy; este vous de lion dites vous.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: De lion, ma cheer dam.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p: Ma cousin! Je suis bien aise de vous voire en bonne disposition?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Man cousin!

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: This is a Frenchman sure.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p:
If he be, 'tis the likest an Englishman that ever I saw, all
his dimensions, proportions! had I but the dissecting of his heart, in capsula cordis, could I find it now; for a Frenchman's heart is more quassitive and subject to tremor, than an Englishman's.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Stay, we'll further inquire of this gentlewoman. Mistress, if you have so much English to help us with (As I think you have, for I have long seen you about London) pray tell us, and truly tell us, is this gentleman a natural Frenchman, or no?

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p: Ey begar, de Frenchman, born a lion, my cousin.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Your cousin? if he be not your cousin, he's my cousin, sure.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p: Ey konoshe his peer, what you call his fadre? he sell poisons.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: Sell poisons, his father was a apothecary then.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: No, no, poisons, what you call, fish, fish?

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: O, he was a fishmonger.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p: Ouy, ouy.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Well, well, we are mistaken I see, pray you so tell him, and request him not to be offended; an honest man may look like a knave, and be never the worse for't, the error was in our eyes, and now we find it in his tongue.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p: Je saieray encore une fois monsieur cousin, pour vostre sawete, ales vous en; vostre liberte est sufisant: je gaineray le rest pour mon devoir, et vous aures vostre part a mon escole: j'ay une filly qui parle un peu Francois, elle conversera avec vous a la fleur de lys en Turnbull-street: mon cousin aies soin de vous mesme, et tromps ces ignorans.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Cousin pour l'amour de vous, et principallement pour moy, je suis content de m'en aller, je troweray vostre escole, et si voz escoliers me sont agreeable, je tireray a l'espe 'Seule, et si d'aventure je le rompe, je paiera diz souls et pour ce vieulx foll, ee ce deux quenailles, ce poullens snip snap, et l'autre bonnet rond, je les voiray pendre premier que je les voie.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: So, so, she has got him off; but I perceive much anger in his countenance still: and what says he, madam?

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p: Moosh, moosh anger, but ey conosh here lodging, shall cool him very well, dear is a kinse-womans can moosh allay here heat and here spleen, she shall do for my saka, and he no trobla you.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Look, there is earnest, but thy reward's behind: come to my shop, the holy lamb in Lombardstreet, thou hast one friend more than e'er thou hadst.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p:
Tanck u monsieur, shall visit u: ey make all pacify:
a vostre service treshumbement, tree, four, five fool of you.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: What's to be done now?

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: To pay us for our pains sir, and better reward us, that we may be provided against further danger that may come upon's for false imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: All goes false I think: what do you neighbour Sweetball?

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: I must phlebotomize sir, but my almanac says the sign is in Taurus; I dare not cut my own throat, but if I find any precedent that ever barber hanged himself, I'll be the second example.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: This was your ill luxinium, barber, to cause all to be cheated.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: What say you to us, sir?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Good friends, come to me at a calmer hour, my sorrows lie in heaps upon me now; what you have, keep, if further trouble follow I'll take it on me; I would be pressed to death.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: Well sir, for this time we'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: I will go with you, officers, I will walk with you in the open street though it be a scandal to me; for now I have no care of my credit, a cacokenny is run all over me.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: What shall we do now, Ralph?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Faith I know not, sir: here comes George, it may be he can tell you.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: And there I look for more disaster still, yet George appears in a smiling countenance. Ralph, home to the shop, leave George and I together.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I am gone, sir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Now George, what better news eastward? all goes ill tother way.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I bring you the best news that ever came about your ears in your life, sir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Thou puttest me in good comfort, George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: My mistress, your wife, will never trouble you more.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Ha? never trouble me more: of this, George, may be made a sad construction, that phrase we sometimes use when death makes the separation, I hope it is not so with her, George?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: No sir, but she vows she'll never come home again to you, so you shall live quietly, and this I took to be very good news, sir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p:
The worst that could be this, candid poison; I love her, George, and I am bound to do so, the tongue's bitterness must not separate the united souls: 'twere base and cowardly for all to yield
to the small tongue's assault: the whole building must not be taken down, for the repairing of a broken window.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I but this is a principal, sir: the truth is, she will be divorced, she says, and is labouring with her cousin knave (What do you call him?) I have forgotten the latter end of his name.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Knavesbee, George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I knave, or Knavesbee, one I took it to be.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Why neither rage, nor envy, can make a cause, George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes sir, not only at your person, but she shoots at your shop too, she says you vent ware that is not warrantable, braided ware, and that you give not London measure: women you know look for more than a bare yard: and than you keep children in the name of your own, which she suspects came not in at the right door

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: She may as well suspect immaculate truth to be cursed falsehood.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I but if she will, she will, she's a woman sir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: 'Tis most true, George: well, that shall be redressed, my cousin Cressingham must yield me pardon, the children shall home again, and thou shalt conduct 'em, George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: That done, I'll be bold to venture once more for her recovery, since you cannot live at liberty; but because you are a rich citizen, you will have your chain about your neck; I think I have a device will bring you together byth' years again, and then look to 'em as well as you can.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: O George, amongst all my heavy troubles, this is the groaning weight; but restore my wife.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Although you never lead hour of quiet life.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: I will endeavour't George, I'll lend her will a power and rule to keep all hushed and still; eat we all sweetmeats we are soonest rotten.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: A sentence! pity 't should have been forgotten. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus iv.
div.stage: Enter sir Francis Cressingham, and a surveyor.

sp.speaker: Surveyor
sp.p: Where's Mr. steward?

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Within: what are you, sir?

sp.speaker: Surveyor
sp.p: A surveyor, sir.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p:
And an almanac-maker, I take it: can you tell me what foul weather
is towards?

sp.speaker: Surveyor
sp.p: Marry the foulest weather is, that your land is flying away.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: A most terrible prognostication! All the resort, all the business to my house is to my lady and Mr. steward; whilst sir Francis stands for a cypher: I have made away myself and my power, as if I had done it by deed of gift: here comes the comptroller of the game.

sp.speaker: Saunder.
sp.p: What, are you yet resolved to translate this unnecessary land into ready money?

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Translate it?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: The conveyances are drawn, and the money ready: my lady sent me to you, to know directly if you meant to go through in the sale; if not, she resolves of another course.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Thou speakest this cheerfully methinks, whereas faithful servants were wont to mourn when they beheld the lord that fed and cherished them, is by cursed enchantment removed into another blood. Cressingham of Cressingham has continued many years, and must the name sink now?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: All this is nothing to my lady's resolution, it must be done, or she'll not stay in England: she would know whether your son be sent for, that must likewise set his hand to th' 'Sale; for otherwise the lawyers say there cannot be a sure conveyance made to the buyer.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Yes, I have sent for him: but I pray thee think what a hard task 't will be for a father to persuade his son and heir to make away his inheritance.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Nay for that, use your own logic: I have heard you talk at the sessions terribly against deer-stealers, and that kept you from being put out of the commission.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: I do live to see two miseries, one to be commanded by my wife, the other to be censured by my slave.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: That which I have wanted long, and has been cause of my irregular courses, I beseech you let raise me from the ground

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Rise George, there's a hundred pounds for you, and my blessing, with these, your mother's favour: but I hear your studies are become too licentious of late.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Has heard of my cozenage.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: What's that you are writing?

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Sir, not any thing.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p:
Come, I hear there's something coming
forth of yours, will be your undoing.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Of mine?

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Yes of your writing; somewhat you should write, will be dangerous to you. I have a suit to you.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Sir, my obedience makes you commander in all things.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: I pray suppose I had committed some fault, for which my life and sole estate were forfeit to the law, and that some great man near the King should labour to get my pardon, on condition he might enjoy my lordship, could you prize your father's life above the grievous loss of your inheritance?

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Yes, and my own life at stake too.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: You promise fair, I come now to make trial of it: you know I have married one whom I hold so dear, that my whole life is nothing but a mere estate depending upon her will, and her affections to me: she deserves so well, I cannot longer merit then durante bene placita, 'tis her pleasure, and (Her wisdom moves in't too) of which I'll give you ample satisfaction hereafter, that I sell the land my father left me: you change colour! I have promised her to do't, and should I fail, I must expect the remainder of my life as full of trouble and vexation, as the suit for a divorce; it lies in you by setting of your hand unto the sale, to add length to his life that gave you yours.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p:
Sir, I do now ingeniously perceive why you said lately, somewhat I should write would be my undoing, meaning (As I take it) setting my hand to this assurance: o good sir, shall I pass away my birthright? O remember there is a malediction denounced against it in holy writ: will you for her pleasure, the inheritance of desolation leave to your posterity? think how compassionate the creatures of the field that only live on the wild benefits of nature, are unto their young ones; think likewise you may have more children by this woman, and by this act you undo them too: 'tis a strange precedent this, to see an obedient son labouring good counsel to the father! But know sir, that the spirits of my great-grandfather and your father moves at this present in me, and what they bequeathed you, on your deathbed they charge you not to give away in the dalliance of a woman's bed: good sir, let it not be thought presumption in me, that I have continued my speech unto this length, the cause sir, is urgent, and believe it you shall find her beauty as malevolent unto you, as a red morning
that doth still foretell a foul day to follow: o sir, keep your land, keep that to keep your name immortal, and you shall see all that her malice and proud will procures,
Shall show her ugly heart, but hurt not yours.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: O I am distracted, and my very soul sends blushes into my cheeks.
sp.stage: Enter George with the two children.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: See here an object to beget more compassion.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: O sir Francis, we have a most lamentable house at home, nothing to be heard in't but separation and divorces, and such a noise of the spiritual court, as if it were a tenement upon London-bridge, and built upon the arches.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: All about boarding your children, my mistress is departed. Cress. Dead?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: In a sort she is, and laid out too, for she is run away from my master.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Seven miles off, into Essex, she vowed never to leave barking while she lived, till these were brought home again.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: O they shall not offend her. I am sorry for't.

sp.speaker: 1 child.
sp.p: I am glad we are come home sir, for we lived in the unquietest house!

sp.speaker: 2 child.
sp.p: The angry woman methought grudged us our victuals: our new mother is a good soul, and loves us, and does not frown so like a vixen as she does.

sp.speaker: 1 child.
sp.p: I am at home now, and in heaven methinks : what a comfort 'tis to be under your wing!

sp.speaker: 2 child.
sp.p: Indeed my mother was wont to call me your nestlecock, and I love you as well as she did.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: You are my pretty souls.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Does not the prattle of these move you?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Look you sir, here's the conveyance and my lady's solicitor, pray resolve what to do, my lady is coming down. How now George, how does thy mistress that sits in a wainscot gown, like a citizen's lure to draw in customers? o she's a pretty mousetrap!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: She's ill baited though to take a Welshman, she cannot away with cheese.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: And what must I do now?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Acknowledge a fine and recovery of the land, then for possession the course is common.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p:
