Carry back the writings sir, my mind is
changed.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Changed! do not you mean to seal?

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: No sir, the tide's turned.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: You must temper him like wax, or he'll not seal.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Are you come back again? How now, have you done?

sp.speaker: 1 child.
sp.p: How do you, lady mother?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You are good children; bid my woman give them some sweetmeats.

sp.speaker: 1 child.
sp.p: Indeed I thank you: is not this a kind mother?

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Poor fools, you know not how dear you shall pay for this sugar.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What, han't you dispatched?

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: No sweetest, I am dissuaded by my son from the sale o'th land.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Dissuaded by your son!

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: I cannot get his hand to't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Where's our steward? cause presently that all my beds and hangings be taken down; provide carts, pack them up, I'll to my house i'th country, have I studied the way to your preferment and your children's, and do you cool i'th upshot?

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: With your pardon, I cannot understand this course a way to any preferment, rather a direct path to our ruin.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O sir, you are young sighted: show them the project of the land I mean to buy in Ireland, that shall outvalue yours three thousand in a year.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Look you sir, here is Clangibbon, a fruitful country, and well wooded.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: What's this, marsh ground?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: No, these are bogs, but a little cost will drain them. This upper part (Map â–ª that runs by the black water, is the Cossacks land, a spacious country, and yields excellent profit by the salmon, and fishing for herring: here runs the Kernes-dale, admirable feed for cattle, and here about is st. Patrick's purgatory.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Purgatory! shall we purchase that too?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come, come, will you dispatch th'other business, we may go through with this?

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: My son's unwilling.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Upon my soul sir, I'll never bed with you till you have sealed.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Thou hearest her: on thy blessing follow me to'th' court, and seal.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Sir, were it my death, were't to'th' loss of my estate, I vow to obey you in all things; yet with it remember there are two young ones living that may curse you: I pray dispose part of the money, on their generous educations.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Fear no you sir: the caroche there, when you have dispatched, you shall find
me at the scriveners where I shall receive the money.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: She'll devour that mass too.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How likest thou my power over him?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This is the height of a great ladies sway,
When her night service makes her rule i'th day.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Not yet Sib? my lord keeps thee so long, thou'rt welcome I see then, and pays sweetly too: a good wench Sib thou'rt, to obey thy husband. She's come: a hundred mark a year, how fine and easy it comes into mine arms now! Welcome home, what says my lord, Sib?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: My lord says you are a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, I thank him for that bob i'faith, I'll afford it him again at the same price a month hence, and let the commodity grow as scarce as it will. Cuckold says his lordship! ha, ha, I shall burst my sides with laughing that's the worst, name not a hundred year, for then I burst. It smarts not so much as a fillip on the forehead by five parts: what has his dalliance taken from thy lips? 'tis as sweet as ere 'twas, let me try else: buss me sugar-candy.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Forbear, you presume to a lord's pleasure!

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: How's that! not I Sib?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Never touch me more, I'll keep the noble stamp upon my lip, no under baseness shall deface it now; you taught me the way, now I am in, I'll keep it, I have kissed ambition, and I love it, I loathe the memory of every touch my lip hath tasted from thee.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Nay but sweet Sib, you do forget yourself.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I will forget all that I ever was, and nourish new sirrah, I am a lady.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Lord bless us madam.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I have enjoyed a lord, that's real possession, and daily shall, the which all ladies have not with their lords.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: But with your patience madam, who was it that preferred you to this ladyship?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: 'Tis all I am beholding to thee for, thou'st brought me out of ignorance into light, simple as I was, I thought thee a man till I found the difference by a man: thou art a beast, a horned beast, an Ox.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Are these ladies' terms?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: For thy pander's fee it shall be laid under the candlestick, look for't, I'll leave it for thee.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: A little lower, good your ladyship, my cousin Chamlet is in the house, let these things go no further.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: 'Tis for mine own credit if I forbear, not thine, thou bugle-browed beast thou.
sp.stage: Enter George with rolls of paper.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Bidden, bidden, bidden, bidden; so, all these are past: but here's as large a walk to come, if I do not get it up at the feast, I shall be leaner for bidding the guests I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: How now! who's this?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Doctor Glister, et; what word's this? fuxor, o uxor, the doctor and his wife: Mr. body et uxor of Bowlane, Mr. Knavesbee et uxor.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Ha, we are in, whatsoever the matter is.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Here's forty couple more in this quarter; but there the provision bringing in, that puzzles me most: one ox, that will hardly serve for beef too; five muttons, ten lambs, poor innocents, they'll be devoured too; three gross of capons.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Mercy upon us! what a slaughterhouse is here!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Two bushels of small birds, plovers, snipes, woodcocks, partridge, larks; then for baked-meats.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: George, George, what feast is this? 'tis not for st. George's day?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Cry you mercy sir, you and your wife are in my roll: my master invites you his guests tomorrow dinner.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Dinner sayst thou? he means to feast a month sure.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Nay sir, you make up but a hundred couple.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Why, what ship has brought an India home to him, that he's so bountiful? or what friend dead (Unknown to us) has so much left to him of arable land, that he means to turn to pasture thus?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis a vessel sir, a good estate comes all in one bottom to him, and 'tis a question whether ever he find the bottom or no; a thousand a year, that's the uppermost.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: A thousand a year!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: To go no further about the bush sir, now the bird is caught; my master is tomorrow to be married, and amongst the rest invites you a guest, at his wedding-dinner the second.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Married!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: There is no other remedy for flesh and blood, that will have leave to play whether we will or no, or wander into forbidden pastures.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Married! why he is married, man; his wife is in my house now, thy mistress is alive, George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: She that was, it may be sir, but dead to him, she played a little too rough with him, and he has discarded her, he's divorced sir.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: He divorced! then is her labour saved; for she was labouring a divorce from him.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: They are well parted then sir.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: But wilt thou not speak with her? I'faith invite her to 't.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: 'Tis not in my commission, I dare not, fare you well sir, I have much business in hand, and the time is short.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Nay but George, I prithee stay, may I report this to her for a certain truth?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Wherefore am I employed in this invitation sir?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Prithee what is she, his second choice?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Truly a goodly presence, likely to bear great children, and great store, she never saw five and thirty summers together in her life by her appearance, and comes in her french-hood, by my fecks a great match 'tis like to be; I am sorry for my old mistress but cannot help it: pray you excuse me now sir, for all the business goes through my hands, none employed but myself.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Why here is news that no man will believe, but he that sees.

sp.speaker: Kna. wife.
sp.p: This, and your cuckoldry, will be digestion throughout the city dinners and suppers, for a month together, there will need no cheese.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: No more of that Sib: I'll call my cousin Chamlet, and make her partaker of this sport; she's come already. Cousin, take't at once, you're a free woman, your late husband's to be married tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Mris. Cham.
sp.p: Married! to whom?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: To a french-hood byrlakins, as I understand, great cheer prepared, and great guests invited, so far I know.

sp.speaker: Mris. Cham.
sp.p: What a cursed wretch was I to pare my nails today, a Friday too; I looked for some mischief.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Why, I did think this had accorded with your best liking, you sought for him what he has sought for you, a separation, and by divorce too.

sp.speaker: Mris. Cham.
sp.p: I'll divorce 'em? Is he to be married to a french-hood? I'll dress it the English fashion; never a coach to be had with six horses to strike fire i'th streets as we go?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Will you go home then?

sp.speaker: Mris. Cham.
sp.p: Good cousin, help me to whet one of my knives, while I sharp the tother, give me a sour apple to set my teeth an edge, I would give five pound for the paring of my nails again: have you ere a bird-spit i'th' house, I'll dress one dish to the wedding.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: This violence hurts yourself the most.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: I care not who I hurt; o my heart, how it beats a both sides; will you run with me for a wager into Lombardstreet now?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I'll walk with you cousin a sufficient pace; Sib. shall come softly after, I'll bring you through Bearbinder-lane.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p:
Bearbinder-lane cannot hold me, I'll the nearest way
over st. Mildred's church, if I meet any french-hoods by the way, I'll make black patches enough for the rheum.

sp.speaker: Kna. wife.
sp.l: So 'tis to my wish, master Knavesbee,
Help to make peace abroad, here you'll find wars,
I'll have a divorce too, with locks and bars.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Madam, but stay here a little, my master comes instantly, I heard him say he did owe you a good turn, and now's the time to take it, I'll warrant you a sound reward ere you go.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ey thank u de bon cour monsieur.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Look he's here already, now would a skilful navigator take in his sails, for sure there is a storm towards.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: O madam I perceive in your countenance (I am beholding to you) all is peace? Mar. all quiet, goor friendship, ey mooch ado , ey strive wid him: give goor worda for you; no more speak a de matra, all es undone u no more trobla.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Look, there's the price of a fair pair of gloves, and wear 'em for my sake.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: O, o, o, my hearts broke out of my ribs.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Nay a little patience.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Ey thank u artely, shall no bestow en gloves, shall put moosh more to dees, an bestow your shop; regard dees stofa my petticoat u no soosh anodre; shall deal wid u for moosh; take in your hand.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: I see it mistress, 'tis good stuff indeed, 'tis a silk rash, I can pattern it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: Shall he take up her coats before my face? O beastly creature; french-hood, french-hood, I will make your hair grow through.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: My wife returned! o welcome home, sweet Rachel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: I forbid the banes, lecher and strumpet, thou shalt bear children without noses.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: O pardonne moy, by my trat ey mean u no hurta: what u meant by dees?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: I will have thine eyes out, and thy bastards shall be as blind as puppies.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Sweet Rachel, good cousin help to pacify.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: I forbid the banes, adulterer.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: What means she by that sir?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Good cousin forbid your rage a while, unless you hear, by what sense will you receive satisfaction?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham
sp.p:
By my hands and my teeth
sir, give me leave, will you bind me whiles mine enemy kills me?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Here all are your friends sweet wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: Wil't have two wives? Do and by hanged fornicator, I forbid the banes; give me the french-hood, I'll tread it under feet in a pair of pantofles.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Begar shall save hood head and all; shall come no more here, ey warrant u..

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Sir, the truth is, report spoke it for truth, you were tomorrow to be married.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: I forbid the banes.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Mercy deliver me, if my grave embrace me in the bed of death, I would to church with willing ceremony; but for my wedlock-fellow, here she is the first and last that ere my thoughts looked on.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Why la you cousin, this was naught but error or an assault of mischief.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Whose report was it?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Your man George's, who invited me to the wedding.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: George? And was he sober? Good sir call him.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: It needs not sir, I am here already.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Did you report this George?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes sir I did.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: And wherefore did you so?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: For a new suit that you promised me sir, if I could bring home my mistress, and I think she's come with a mischief.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: Give me that villain's ears.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I would give ear, if I could hear you talk wisely.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: Let me cut off his ears.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I shall hear worse of you hereafter then, limb for limb, one of my ears, for one of your tongues, and I'll lay out for my master.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: 'Twas knavery with a good purpose in't, sweet Rachel, this was e'en George's meaning, a second marriage 'twixt thyself and me, and now I woo the to't, a quiet night will make the sun like a fresh bridegroom rise, and kiss the chaste cheek of the rosy morn which we will imitate, and like him create fresh buds of love, fresh spreading arms, fresh fruit, fresh wedding robes, and George's fresh new suit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: This is fine stuff, have you much on't to sell?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: A remnant of a yard.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Come, come, all's well, sir, you must sup, instead of to morrows dinner.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.l: I follow you; no: 'tis another way,
My lords reward calls me to better cheer
many good meals a hundred marks a year;
My wife's transformed a lady, tush, she'll come to her shape again,
My lord rides the circuit,
If I rid along with him, what need I grutch
I can as easy sit, and speed as much.

div.head: Actus. V.
div.stage: Enter old Franklin in mourning: young Cressingham with young Franklin disguised like an old servingman.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: Sir, your son's death which has apparelled you in this darker wearing, is a loss wherein I have ample share; he was my friend.

sp.speaker: Old Fran.
sp.p: He was my nearest and dearest enemy, and the perpetual fear of a worse end had he continued his former dissolute course, makes me weigh his death the lighter.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Yet sir, with your pardon, if you value him every way as he deserved, it will appear your scanting of his means, and the lord Beaufort's most unlordly breach of promise to him, made him fall upon some courses, to which his nature and mine own, (Made desperate likewise by the cruelty of a mother in law) would else have been as strange, as insolent greatness is to distressed virtue.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Yes, I have heard of that too; your defeat made upon a mercer, I style't modestly, the law intends it plain cozenage.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: 'Twas no less, but my penitence and restitution, may come fairly off from't; it was no impeachment to the glory won at Agincourt's great battle, that the achiever of it in his youth had been a purse-taker, this with all reverence to'th great example. Now to my business, wherein you have made such noble trial of your worth, that in a world so dull as this, where faith is almost grown to be a miracle, I have found a friend so worthy as yourself, to purchase all the land my father sold at the persuasion of a riotous woman, and charitable to reserve it for his use, and the good of his three children; this I say, is such a deed shall style you our preserver, and owe the memory of your worth, and pay it to all posterity.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Sir, what I have done, looks to the end of the good deed itself, no other way i'th world.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p:
But would you please out of a friendly reprehension,
to make him sensible of the weighty wrong he has done his children, yet I would not have it too bitter, for he undergoes already such torment in a woman's naughty pride, too harsh reproof would kill him.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Leave you that to my discretion: I have made myself my son's executor, and am come up on purpose to collect his creditors, and where I find his pennyworth conscionable, I'll make them in part satisfaction:
O this fellow was born near me, and his trading here i'th city may bring me to the knowledge of the men my son ought money to.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Your worship's welcome to London, and I pray how does all our good friends i'th country?

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: They are well, George: how thou art shot up since I saw thee? what, I think thou art almost out of thy time?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I am out of my wit's sir, I have lived in a kind of bedlam these four years, how can I be mine own man then?

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I may turn soap-boiler, I have a loose body: I am turned away from my master.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: How! turned away! Indenture.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I am gone sir, not in drink, and yet you may behold my indentures: o the wicked wit of woman, for the good turn I did bringing her home, she never left sucking my master's breath, like a cat, kissing him I mean, till I was turned away!

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: I have heard she's a terrible woman.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes, and the miserablest! her sparing in housekeeping has cost him somewhat, the dagger-pyes can testify: she has stood in's light most miserably, like your fasting-days before red letters in the almanac: saying, the pinching of our bellies would be a mean to make him wear scarlet the sooner. She had once persuaded him to have bought spectacles for all his servants, that they might have worn 'em dinner and supper.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: To what purpose?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Marry, to have made our victuals seem bigger than 't was: she shows from whence she came, that my wind-colic can witness.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Why, whence came she?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Marry from a courtier, and an officer too, that was up and down I know not how often.

sp.speaker: Old. Fra.
sp.p: Had he any great place?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes, and a very high one, but he got little by it; he was one that blew the organ in the court chapel, our Puritans, especially your Puritans in Scotland, could never away with him.

sp.speaker: Old. Fran.
sp.p: Is she one of the sect?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p:
Faith I think not,
for I am certain, she denies her husband the supremacy.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Well George, your difference may be reconciled. I am now to use your help in a business that concerns me: here's a note of men's names here i'th' city, unto whom my son ought money, but I do not know their dwelling?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Let me see sir: fifty pound taken up at use of Mr. water thin the brewer.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: What's he?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: An obstinate fellow, and one that denied payment of the groats, till he lay by th' heels for't; I know him: item, fourscore pair of provant breeches a'th'new fashion, to pinch buttock a hosier in Burchen-lane, so much.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: What the devil did he with so many pair of breeches?

sp.speaker: Yo. Fran.
sp.p: Supply a captain sir, a friend of his went over to the palatinate.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Item, to my tailor Mr. Wetherwise, by st. Clements-church.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: Who should that be? it may be 'tis the new prophet, the astrological tailor.

sp.speaker: Yo. Frank.
sp.p: No, no, no sir, we have nothing to do with him.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Well, I'll read no further, leave the note to my discretion, do not fear but I'll inquire them all.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Why, I thank thee.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Sir, rest assured I shall in all your business be faithful to you, and at better leisure find time to imprint deeply in your father, the wrong he has done you,
sp.stage: Exeunt. Old Franklin, George, and young Franklin.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: You are worthy in all things?
Is my father stirring?

sp.speaker: Saund.
sp.p: Yes, sir, my lady wonders you are thus chargeable to your father, and will not direct yourself unto some gainful study, may quit him of your dependence.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: What study?

sp.speaker: Saund.
sp.p: Why the law, that law that takes up most o'th' wits i'th kingdom, not for most good, but most gain, or divinity; I have heard you talk well, and I do not think but you'd prove a singular fine churchman.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: I should prove a plural better, if I could attain to fine benefices.

sp.speaker: Saund.
sp.p: My lady now she has money, is studying to do good works, she talked last night what a goodly act it was, of a countess (Northamptonshire breed belike, or thereabouts) that to make Coventry a corporation, road through the city naked, and by day light.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: I do not think, but you have ladies living would discover as much in private, to advance but some member of a corporation.

sp.speaker: Saund.
sp.p:
Well sir, your wit is still goring at my lady's projects:
here's your father.

sp.speaker: Old Cress.
sp.p: Thou com'st to chide me, hearing how like a ward I am handled, since the sale of my land.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: No sir, but to turn your eyes into your own bosom.

sp.speaker: Old Cress.
sp.p: Why, I am become my wife's pensioner; am confined to a hundred mark a year, t'one suit, and one man to attend me.

sp.speaker: Saund.
sp.p: And is not that enough for a private gentleman?

sp.speaker: Old Cress.
sp.p: Peace sirrah, there is nothing but knave speaks in thee, and my two poor children must be put forth to prentice.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: Ha! to prentice: sir, I do not come to grieve you, but to show how wretched your estate was that you could not come to see order, until foul disorder pointed the way to't, so inconsiderate, yet so fruitful still is dotage to beget its own destruction.

sp.speaker: Old Cress.
sp.p: Surely I am nothing, and desire to be so, pray thee fellow entreat her only to be quiet, I have given her all my estate on that condition.

sp.speaker: Saund.
sp.p: Yes sir, her coffers are well lined believe me.

sp.speaker: Old Cress.
sp.p: And yet she is not contented; we observe the moon is never so pleasant, and so clear as when she is at the full.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: You did not use my mother with this observance, you are like the frogs, who weary of their quiet King, consented to the election of the stork, who in the end devoured them.

sp.speaker: Old Cress.
sp.p: You may see how apt man is to forfeit all his judgement upon the instant of his fall.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: Look up sir.

sp.speaker: Old Cress.
sp.p: O my hearts broke; weighty are injuries that come from an enemy, but those are deadly that come from a friend, forEnter the lady Cressingham.we see commonly those are ta'en most to heart: she comes.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: What a terrible eye she darts on us.

sp.speaker: Old Cress.
sp.p: O most natural, for lightning to go before the thunder.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What? Are you in council? are ye levying faction against us.

sp.speaker: Old Cress.
sp.p: Good friend.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, sir, pray come hither, there is winter in your looks, a latter winter, do you complain to your kindred? I'll make you fear extremely, to show you have any cause to fear: are the bonds sealed for the six thousand pounds I put forth to use?

sp.speaker: Saund.
sp.p: Yes madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: The bonds were made in my uncle's name.

sp.speaker: Saund.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Old Cress.
sp.p: 'Tis strange though.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Nothing strange, you'll think the allowance I have put you to as strange, but your
judgement cannot reach the aim I have in't: you were pricked last year to be high sheriff, and what it would have cost you I understand now, all this charge and the other by the sale of your land, and the money at my dispose, and your pension so small, will settle you in quiet, make you master of a retired life, and our great ones may think you a politic man, and that you are aiming at some strange business, having made all over.

sp.speaker: Old Cress.
sp.p: I must leave you, man is never truly awake till he be dead.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: What a dream have you made of my father?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Let him be so, and keep the proper place of dreams; his bed, until I raise him.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: Raise! him not unlikely, 'tis you have ruined him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You do not come to quarrel?

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: No certain, but to persuade you to a thing, that in the virtue of it, nobly carries its own commendation, and you shall gain much honour by it, which is the recompense of all virtuous actions, to use my father kindly.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why? does he complain to you sir?

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: Complain: why should a King complain for any thing, but for his sins to heaven, the prerogative of husband is like to his, over his wife.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am full of business sir, and will not mind you.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: I must not leave you thus; I tell you mother 'tis dangerous to a woman, when her mind raises her to such height, it makes her only capable of her own merit; nothing of duty! o, 'twas a strange unfortunate o'erprizing your beauty, brought him, (Otherwise discreet) into the fatal neglect of his poor children: what will you give us of the late sum you received?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Not a penny; away, you are troublesome and saucy.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: You are too cruel: denials even from princes who may do what they list, should be supplied with a gracious verbal usage, that though they do not cure the sore, they may abate the sense of't; the wealth you seem to command over, is his, and he I hope will dispose of't to our use.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: When he can command my will?

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: Have you made him so miserable, that he must take a law from his wife?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Have you not had some lawyers forced to groan under the burden?

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: Oh! but the greater the women, the more visible are their vices.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
So sir, you have been so bold; by all can
bind an oath, and I'll not break it, I will not be the woman to you hereafter you expected.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: Be not; be not yourself, be not my father's wife, be not my lady Cressingham, and then I'll thus speak to you, but you must not answer in your own person.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A fine puppet play!

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: Good madam, please you pity the distress of a poor gentleman, that is undone by a cruel mother in law, you do not know her, nor does she deserve the knowledge of any good one, for she does not know herself, you would sigh for her that ere she took you sex, if you but heard her qualities.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This is a fine crotchet.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: Envy and pride, flow in her painted breasts, she gives no other suck; all her attendants do not belong to her husband, his money is hers, marry his debts are his own, she bears such sway, she will not suffer his religion be his own, but what she please to turn it to.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And all this while, I am the woman you libel against.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: I remember ere the land was sold, you talked of going to Ireland, but should you touch there, you would die presently.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why man?

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: The country brooks no poison: go, you'll find how difficult a thing it is, to make a settled or assured estate of things ill gotten: when my father's dead, the curse of lust and riot follow you, marry some young gallant that may rifle you; yet add one blessing to your needy age, that you may die full of repentance.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ys. Cress.
sp.p: Oh! she's lost to any kind of goodness.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sirrah, be gone, you're base.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Base, my good lord? 'tis a ground part in music, trebles, means, all his but sidling, your honour bore a part as my wife says, my lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Your wife's a strumpet.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Ah ha, is she so? I am glad to hear it, open confession, open payment, the wagers mine then, a hundred a year my lord, I said so before, and staked my head against it, thus after darksome night, the day is come, my lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Hence, hide thy branded head, let no day see thee, nor thou any but thy execution day.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: That's the day after washing day, once a week, I see't at home my lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p:
Go home and see thy prostituted wife (For sure 'tis so) now folded in a boy's adultery, my page; on whom the hot-rained harlot dotes, this night he hath been her attendant, my house he's
fled from, and must no more return, go, and make haste sir, lest your reward be lost for want of looking to.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: My reward lost; is there nothing due for what is past, my lord?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Yes pander, wittol, Macrio, basest of knaves, thou boulster-bawd to thine own infamy! go, I have no more about me at this time, when I am better stored thou shalt have more where'er I meet thee.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Pander, wittol, Macrio, base knave, bolster bawd; here is but five mark towards a hundred a year: this is poor payment, if lords may be trusted no better than thus! I will go home and cut my wife's nose off, I will turn over a new leaf, and hang up the page; lastly I will put on a large pair of wet-leather boots and drown myself, I will sink at queen-hive, and rise again at Charingcross contrary to the statute in Edwardo primo.

div.stage: Enter old Franklin; his son as before, George, three or four citizens, creditors.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Good health to your lordship.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Mr. franklin, I heard of your arrival, and the cause of this your sad appearance.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: And 'tis no more than as your honour says, indeed appearance, it has more form than feeling sorrow sir, I must confess, there's none of these gentlemen (Though aliens in blood) but have as large cause of grief as I.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.p: No, by your favour sir, we are well satisfied; there was in his life a greater hope, but less assurance.

sp.speaker: 2 Cred.
sp.p: Sir, I wish all my debts of no better promise to pay me thus, fifty in the hundred comes fairly homewards.

sp.speaker: Young Frank.
sp.p: Considering hard bargains and dead commodities, sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Cred.
sp.p: Thou sayst true, friend, and from a dead debtor too.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And so you have compounded and agreed all your sons riotous debts?

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: There's behind but one cause of worse condition, that done, he may sleep quietly.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.p: Yes sure my lord, this gentleman is come a wonder to us all, that so fairly with half a loss could satisfy those debts were dead, even with his son, and from whom we could have nothing claimed.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: I showed my reason; I would have a good name live after him, because he bore my name.

sp.speaker: 2 Cred.
sp.p: May his tongue perish first (And that will spoil his trade) that first gives him a syllable of ill.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why this is friendly.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: My lord!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Mr. Chamlet! very welcome.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p:
Mr. franklin, I
take it, these gentlemen I know well: good Mr. Pennystone, Mr. Philip, Mr. Cheyney! I am glad I shall take my leave of so many of my good friends at once; your hand first, my lord, fare you well sir, nay I must have all your hands to my pass.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Will you have mine too sir?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Yes, thy two hands George, and I think two honest hands of a tradesman, George, as any between Cornhill and Lombardstreet.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Take heed what you say sir, there's Birchen-lane between 'em.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But what's the cause of this, Mr. Chamlet?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: I have the cause in handling, now my lord; George, honest George is the cause, yet no cause of George's, George is turned away one way, and I must go another.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And whither is your way sir?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: E'en to seek out a quiet life, my lord: I do hear of a fine peaceable island.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why 'tis the same you live in.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: No, 'tis so famed, but we th'inhabitants find it not so; the place I speak of has been kept with thunder, with frightful lightnings, amazing noises, but now (Th'enchantment broke) 'tis the land of peace, where hogs and tobacco yield fair increase.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: This is a little wild methinks.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Gentlemen, fare you well, I am for the Bermudas.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Nay, good sir stay, and is that your only cause, the loss of George?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: The loss of George, my lord! make you that no cause? why but examine, would it not break the stout heart of a nobleman to lose his George, much more the tender bosom of a citizen.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Fie, fie, I'm sorry your gravity should run back to lightness thus: you go to the Bermothes!

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Better to Ireland sir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: The land of ire, that's too near home, my wife will be heard from Hellbree to Divellin.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Sir, I must of necessity a while detain you: I must acquaint you with a benefit that's coming towards you. You were cheated of some goods of late, come, I'm a cunning-man, and will help you to the most part again, or some reasonable satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: That's another cause of my unquiet life, sir; can you do that, I may chance stay another tide or two: my wife! (I must speak more private with you) by forty foot pain of death, I dare not reach her: no words of me sweet gentlemen.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I had need hide too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: O, my lord, I have scarce tongue enough yet to tell you; my husband, my husband's gone from me, your warrant good my lord, I never had such need of your warrant; my husband's gone from me.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Going he is, 'tis true; has ta'en his leave of me, and all these gentlemen, and 'tis your sharp tongue that whips him forwards.

sp.speaker: Mris. Cham.
sp.p: A warrant, good my lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You turn away his servants, such on whom his estate depends he says, who know his books, his debts, his customers; the form and order of all his affairs you make orderless, chiefly his George you have banished from him.

sp.speaker: Mris. Cham.
sp.p: My lord, I will call George again.

sp.speaker: George within.
sp.p: Call George again.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why hark you, how high voiced you are, that raise an echo from my cellarage which we with modest loudness cannot.

sp.speaker: Mris. Cham.
sp.p: My lord, do you think I speak too loud?

sp.speaker: George within.
sp.p: Too loud.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why hark, your own tongue answers you, and reverberates your words into your teeth.

sp.speaker: Mris. Cham.
sp.p: I will speak lower all the days of my life: I never found the fault in myself till now, your warrant good my lord, to stay my husband.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Well, well, it shall o'ertake him, ere he pass Gravesend, provided that he meet his quietness at home, else he's gone again.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: And withal to call George again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: I will call George again.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Call George again.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: See, you are raised again, the echo tells you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: I did forget myself indeed, my lord: this is my last fault, I will go make a silent enquiry after George, I will whisper half a score porters in the ear, that shall run softly up and down the city to seek him. Bye ye my lord, buoy all gentlemen. exit

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: George, your way lies before you now, cross the street, and come into her eyes, your master's journey will be stayed.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I'll warrant you bring it to better subjection yet.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: These are fine flashes: how now Mr. Chamlet?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: I had one ear lent to you-ward, my lord, and this o'th tother side, both sounded sweetly: I have whole recovered my late losses sir, th'one half paid, the to'ther is forgiven.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Then your journey is stayed?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p:
Alas my lord, that was a trick of age, for I had left never
a trick of youth like it, to succour me.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: How now? what new object's here!

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: The next man we meet shall judge us.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Content, though he be but a common-council-man.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: The one's a knave, I could know him at twelve score distance.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: And to'ther is a barber-surgeon, my lord.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I'll go no further, here is the honourable lord, that I know will grant my request; my lord â€”

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: Peace, I will make it plain to his lordship: my lord, a covenant by jus jurandum is between us, he is to suffocate my respiration by his capistrum, and I to make incision so far as mortification by his jugulars.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: This is not altogether so plain neither, sir.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: I can speak no plainer my lord, unless I wrong mine art.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I can my lord, I know some part of the law, I am to take him in this place where I find him, and lead him from hence to the place of execution, and there to hang him till he dies; he in equal courtesy is to cut my throat with his razor, and there's an end of both on's.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: There is the end my lord, but we want the beginning: I stand upon it to be strangled first, before I touch either his gula or cervix.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I am against it, for how shall I be sure to have my throat cut after he's hanged.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Is this a condition betwixt you?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: A firm covenant, signed and sealed by oath and handfast, and wants nothing but agreement.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: A little pause: what might be the cause on either part?

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: My passions are grown to putrefaction, and my griefs are gangrened; Mr. Chamlet has scarified me all over, besides the loss of my new brush.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I am kept out of mine own castle, my wife keeps the hold against me: your page my lord, is her champion; I summoned a parley at the window, was answered with defiance: they confess they have lain together, but what they have done else I know not.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Thou canst have no wrong that deserves pity, thou art thyself so bad.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I thank your honour for that, let me have my throat cut then.
sp.stage: Enter Selenger as a woman, and mrs. Knavesbee.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Sir, I can give you a better remedy than his capistrum; your ear a little.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: I come with a bold innocence to answer the best and worst that can accuse me here.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Your husband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p:
He's the worst, I dare his
worst.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Your page, your page.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: We lay together in bed, it is confessed; you, and your ends of law makes worse of it, I did it for reward.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I'll hear no more of this, come gentlemen will you walk?

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: My lord, a little stay; you'll see a sight that neighbour amity will be much pleased with, 'tis come already, my father sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: There must be cause certain for this good change: sir, you are bravely met, this is at the best I ever saw you.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: My lord, I am amazement to myself; I slept in poverty, and am awake into this wonder; how I can thus brave, my dreams did not so much as tell me of; I am of my kind sons new making up, it exceeds the pension much, that yesternight allowed me, and my pockets centupled, but I am my son's child, sir, he knows of me more than I do myself.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Sir, you yet have but earnest of your happiness, a pinnace fore-riding a goodly vessel, by this near anchor-bulked like a castle, and with jewels fraught, (Joys above jewels sir,) from deck to keel, make way for the receipt, empty your bosom of all griefs and troubles, leave not a sigh to beat her back again, she is so stored you'd need have room enough, to take her lading.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: If one commodity be wanting now, all this is nothing.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Tush, that must out too, there must be no remembrance, not the thought that ever youth in woman did abuse you, that e'er your children had a stepmother, that you sold lands to please your punishment, that you were circumscribed and taken in, abridged the large extendure of your grounds, and put into the pinfold that belonged to't, that your son did cheat for want of maintenance; that he did beg, you shall remember only, for I have begged off all these troubles from you.

div.stage: Enter lady Cress. in civil habit, saund. and children very gallant.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: This was a good weeks labour.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: Not an hours my lord, but 'twas a happy one; see sir, a new day shines on you.

sp.speaker: La. Cress.
sp.p: O sir, your son has robbed me.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Ha! that way I instructed?

sp.speaker: The Cress.
sp.p: Nay, hear her sir.

sp.speaker: La. Cress.
sp.p: Of my good purpose sir, he hath forced out of me, what lay concealed, ripened my pity with his dews of duty, forgive me sir, and but keep the number of every grief that I have pained you with, I'll tenfold pay with fresh obedience.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: O, that my wife were here to learn this lesson.

sp.speaker: Lady Cress.
sp.p: Your state is not abated, what was yours, is still your own, and take the cause withal of my harsh seeming usage; it was to reclaim faults in yourself, the swift consumption of many large revenues, gaiming, that of not much less speed, burning up house and land, not casual but cunning fire, which though it keeps the chimney, and outward shows like hospitality, is only devourer on't, consuming chemistry; there I have made you a flat banquet-out; all your stillatories and labouring minerals are demolished, that part of hell in your house is extinct, put out your desire with them, and then these feet shall level with my hands, until you raise my stooped humility to higher grace, to warm these lips with love, and duty do to every silver hair, each one shall be a senator to my obedience.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: All this I know before, whoever of you that had but one ill thought of this good woman, you owe a knee to her, and she is merciful if she forgive you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: That shall be private penance sir, we'll all joy in public with you.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: On the conditions I tell you, not else.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: Sweet George, dear George, any conditions.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: My wife!

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Peace, George is bringing her to conditions.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Good ones, good George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: You shall never talk your voice above the key, sol, sol, sol.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: Sol, sol, sol, I George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Say welcome home honest George, in that pitch.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: Welcome home honest George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Why this is well now.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: That's well indeed, George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Rogue, nor rascal must never come out of your mouth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: They shall never come in, honest George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Nor I will not have you call my master plain husband, that's too course, but as your gentlewomen in the country use, and your persons wives in the town, 'tis comely, and shall be customed in the city, call him master Chamlet at every word.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: At every word, honest George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Look you, there he is, salute him then.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: Welcome home, good Mr. Chamlet.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Thanks, and a thousand sweet wife; I may say honest George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p:
Yes sir, or bird, or chuck, or heart's ease,
or plain Rachel, but call her Rac no more, so long as she is quiet.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: God-a-mercy, shalt have thy new suit a Sunday George.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cham.
sp.p: George shall have two new suits, Mr. Chamlet.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: God-a-mercy, i'faith chuck.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: Mr. Chamlet, you and I are friends, all even betwixt us?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: I do acquit thee, neighbour Sweetbal.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: I will not be hanged then, Knares-bee do thy worst; nor I will not cut thy throat.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I must do't myself.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: If thou comest to my shop, and usurpest my chair of maintenance, I will go as near as I can, but I will not do't.

sp.speaker: Young Cress.
sp.p: No, 'tis I must cut Knaves-bee's throat, for slandering a modest gentlewoman, and my wife in shape of your page, my lord, in her own I durst not place her so near your lordship.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: No more of that sir, if your ends have acquired their own events, crown 'em with your own joy.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cress.
sp.p: Down a your knees Knavesbee, to your wife, she's too honest for you.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: Down, down, before you are hanged, 'twill be to late afterwards, and long thou canst not scape it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: You'll play the pander no more, will you?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: O, that's an inch into my throat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: And let out your wife for her?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: O sweet wife, go no deeper.

sp.speaker: Mris. Kna.
sp.p: Dare any be bail for your better behaviour?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Yes, yes I dare, he will mend one day.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kna.
sp.p: And be worse the next.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.l: Hang me the third then, dear merciful wife,
I will do any thing for a quiet life.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: All then is reconciled?

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: Only my brush is lost, my dear new brush.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: I will help you to satisfaction for that too sir.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: O, sperma caete, I feel it heal already.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I have fully satisfied my dead sons debts?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: All pleased, all paid sir.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p:
Then once more here I bring him back to life, from my servant to my son, nay, wonder not; I have not dealt by fallacy with any, my son was dead, whoe'er out lives his virtues is a dead man, for when you hear of spirits that walk in real bodies, to the amaze and cold astonishment of such as meet 'em, and all would shun; those are men of vices, who nothing have but what is visible, and so by consequence they have no souls, but if the soul return
but if the soul return he lives again,
sp.l: Created newly; such my son appears
By my blessing rooted, growing by his tears.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: You have beguiled us honestly sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And you shall have your brush again.

sp.speaker: Barber.
sp.p: My basins shall all ring for joy

sp.speaker: Beaufort.
sp.p: Why this deserves a triumph, and my cost shall begin a feast to't, to which I do invite you all; such happy reconcilements must not be passed without a health of joy,
sp.l: Discorded friends atoned, men and their wives
This hope proclaims your after quiet lives.

div.head: Epilogue
div.l: I am sent to inquire your censure, and to know
How you stand affected? whether we do owe
Our service to your favours, or must strike
Our sails (Though full of hope) to your dislike:
Howe'er be pleased to think we purposed well,
And from my fellows thus much I must tell,
Instruct us but in what we went astray,
And to redeem it, we'll take any way.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
